title: Optimizing Agricultural Practices: Balancing Manure Use and Minimizing Compaction

tasks.task: Presenting studies on manure application effects on soil compaction, physical properties, and manure management.
subtasks: Explain differences between poultry and cattle manure in nutrient content and moisture levels (categorized as nutrients, moisture, and impact on soil properties).
Emphasize the importance of soil moisture, field traffic, and application methods in manure compaction impacts.
Highlight soil organic matter, soil structure, and root growth as critical factors in manure's effect on soil compaction and resilience.

Discuss a South Dakota study on manure application rates (phosphorus-based PM, nitrogen-based NM, and high-manure HM) versus inorganic fertilizer and control, showing bulk density decreases and soil structure improvements in surface layers.

tasks.task: Investigate a comparison of no-till and conventional till systems with solid and liquid manure application in Wisconsin, highlighting disturbances' impact on soil compaction, aggregation, and micropores.
subtasks: Present bulk density, soil structure, and carbon content results, noting conventional till systems' greater disturbances compared to no-till.
Visualize elemental distribution and correlate elements like calcium with soil structure and stability, emphasizing manure's role in organic matter and elemental content.
